qas.question: As of 2012, what accounts for about half of new nameplate electrical capacity?
What involves the deployment of three generations of renewable energy technologies dating back more than 100 years?
Name one second-generation technology that is market ready.
As of 2013, what accounts for about half of new nameplate electrical capacity
What involves the deployment of three generations of renewable energy technologies dating back more than 10 years?
Name one third-generation technology that is market ready.

context: <a1_0><b3_0><b4_0>Renewable energy<b3_0/> commercialization<b4_0/><a1_0/> involves the deployment of three generations of renewable energy technologies dating back more than 100 years. First-generation technologies, which are already mature and economically competitive, include biomass, hydroelectricity, geothermal power and heat. Second-generation technologies are market-ready and are being deployed at the present time; they include solar heating, photovoltaics, <a2_0><b5_0>wind power<b5_0/><a2_0/>, solar thermal power stations, and modern forms of bioenergy. Third-generation technologies require continued R&D efforts in order to make large contributions on a global scale and include advanced biomass gasification, hot-dry-rock geothermal power, and ocean energy. As of 2012, <a0_0>renewable energy<a0_0/> accounts for about half of new nameplate electrical capacity installed and costs are continuing to fall.
